Sir Anthony's presence prevented my proposed expostulations:—yet I must be satisfied that she has not been so very happy in my absence.—She is coming!—Yes!—I know the nimbleness of her tread, when she thinks her impatient Faulkland counts the moments of her stay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I had not hop'd to see you again so soon.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Could I, Julia, be contented with my first welcome—restrained as we were by the presence of a third person?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O Faulkland, when your kindness can make me thus happy, let me not think that I discovered more coolness in your first salutation than my long-hoarded joy could have presaged.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Twas but your fancy, Julia.—I was rejoiced to see you—to see you in such health—Sure I had no cause for coldness?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay then, I see you have taken something ill.—You must not conceal from me what it is.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Well then—shall I own to you—but you will despise me, Julia—nay, I despise myself for it.—Yet I will own, that my joy at hearing of your health and arrival here, by your neighbour Acres, was something damped, by his dwelling much on the high spirits you had enjoyed in Devonshire—on your mirth—your singing—dancing, and I know not what!—For such is my temper, Julia, that I should regard every mirthful moment in your absence as a treason to constancy: —The mutual tear that steals down the cheek of parting lovers is a compact, that no smile shall live there till they meet again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Must I never cease to tax my Faulkland with this teasing minute caprice?—Can the idle reports of a silly boor weigh in your breast against my tried affection?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: They have no weight with me, Julia: no, no—I am happy if you have been so—yet only say, that you did not sing with mirth—say that you thought of Faulkland in the dance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I never can be happy, in your absence.— If I wear a countenance of content, it is to shew that my mind holds no doubt of my Faulkland's truth.—If I seem'd sad—it were to make malice triumph; and say, that I had fixed my heart on one, who left me to lament his roving, and my own credulity.—Believe me, Faulkland, I mean not to upbraid you, when I say, that I have often dressed sorrow in smiles, lest my friends should guess whose unkindness had caused my tears.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You were ever all goodness to me.—O, I am a brute, when I but admit a doubt of your true constancy!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If ever, without such cause from you, as I will not suppose possible, you find my affections veering but a point, may I become a proverbial scoff for levity, and base ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Ah! Julia, that last word is grating to me. I would I had no title to your gratitude! Search your heart, Julia; perhaps what you have mistaken for Love, is but the warm effusion of a too thankful heart!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: For what quality must I love you?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: For no quality! To regard me for any quality of mind or understanding, were only to esteem me. And for person—I have often wish'd myself deformed, to be convinced that I owed no obligation there for any part of your affection.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Where Nature has bestowed a shew of nice attention in the features of a man, he should laugh
at it, as misplaced. I have seen men, who in this vain article perhaps might rank above you; but my heart has never asked my eyes if it were so or not.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now this is not well from you, Julia—I despise person in a man—Yet if you lov'd me as I wish, though I were an Aethiop, you'd think none so fair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I see you are determined to be unkind.— The contract which my poor father bound us in gives you more than a lover's privilege.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Again, Julia, you raise ideas that feed and justify my doubts.—I would not have been more free—no—I am proud of my restraint.— Yet—yet—perhaps your high respect alone for this solemn compact has fettered your inclinations, which else had made worthier choice.—How shall I be sure, had you remained unbound in thought and promise, that I should still have been the object of your persevering love?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then try me now.—Let us be free as strangers as to what is past:—my heart will not feel more liberty!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: There now! so hasty, Julia! so anxious to be free!—If your love for me were fixed and ardent, you would not loose your hold, even tho' I wish'd it!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O, you torture me to the heart!—I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
I do not mean to distress you.—If I lov'd you less, I should never give you an uneasy moment.—But hear me.—All my fretful doubts arise from this—Women are not used to weigh, and separate the motives of their affections:—the cold dictates of prudence, gratitude, or filial duty, may sometimes be mistaken for the pleadings of the heart.—I would not boast—yet let me say, that I have neither age, person, or character, to found
dislike on;—my fortune such as few ladies could be charged with indiscretion in the match.—O Julia! when Love receives such countenance from Prudence, nice minds will be suspicious of its birth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know not whither your insinuations would tend:—as they seem pressing to insult me—I will spare you the regret of having done so.—I have given you no cause for this!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: In Tears! stay, Julia: stay but for a moment.—The door is fastened!—Julia!— my soul—but for one moment:—I hear her sobbing!—'Sdeath! what a brute am I to use her thus! Yet stay.—Aye—she is coming now:—how little resolution there is in woman!—how a few soft words can turn them!—No, faith!—she is not coming either.—Why, Julia—my love— say but that you forgive me—come but to tell me that—now, this is being too resentful:—stay! she is coming too—I thought she would—no steadiness in any thing! her going away must have been a mere trick then—she sha'n't see that I was hurt by it.—I'll affect indifference—(hums a tune: then listens)—No—Z—ds! she's not coming!— nor don't intend it, I suppose.—This is not steadiness, but obstinacy! Yet I deserve it.—What, after so long an absence, to quarrel with her tenderness! —'twas barbarous and unmanly!—I should be ashamed to see her now.—I'll wait till her just resentment is abated—and when I distress her so again, may I lose her for ever! and be linked instead to some antique virago, whose knawing passions, and long-hoarded spleen, shall make me curse my folly half the day, and all the night!

div2.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Your being Sir Anthony's son, Captain, would itself be a sufficient accommodation;—but from the ingenuity of your appearance, I am convinced you deserve the character here given of you.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Permit me to say, Madam, that as I never yet have had the pleasure of seeing Miss Languish, my principal inducement in this affair at present, is the honour of being allied to Mrs. Malaprop; of whose intellectual accomplishments, elegant manners, and unaffected learning, no tongue is silent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir, you do me infinite honour!— I beg, Captain, you'll be seated.—(Sit)—Ah! few gentlemen, now a days, know how to value the ineffectual qualities in a woman! few think how a little knowledge become a gentlewoman! Men have no sense now but for the worthless flower, beauty!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: It is but too true indeed, Ma'am;—yet I fear our ladies should share the blame—they think our admiration of beauty so great, that knowledge in them would be superfluous. Thus, like gardentrees, they seldom shew fruits, till time has robb'd them of the more specious blossom.—Few, like Mrs. Malaprop and the Orange-tree, are rich in both at once!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Sir—you overpower me with goodbreeding.—He is the very Pine-apple of politeness! You are not ignorant, Captain, that this giddy girl has somehow contrived to fix her affections on a beggarly, strolling, eve's-dropping Ensign,
whom none of us have seen, and nobody knows any thing of.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, I have heard the silly affair before.— I'm not at all prejudiced against her on that account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You are very good, and very considerate, Captain.—I am sure I have done every thing in my power since I exploded the affair! long ago I laid my positive conjunction on her never to think on the fellow again;—I have since laid Sir Anthony's preposition before her;—but I'm sorry to say she seems resolved to decline every particle that I enjoin her.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: It must be very distressing indeed, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: It gives me the hydrostatics to such a degree!—I thought she had persisted from corresponding with him; but behold this very day, I have interceded another letter from the fellow! I believe I have it in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O the devil! my last note.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, here it is.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Aye, my note indeed! O the little traitress Lucy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: There, perhaps you may know the writing.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I think I have seen the hand before—yes, I certainly must have seen this hand before:—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, but read it, Captain.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: (Reads) My soul's idol, my ador'd Lydia! —Very tender indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Tender! aye, and prophane too, o' my conscience!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I am excessively alarmed at the intelligence you send me, the more so as my new rival—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: That's you, Sir.
has universally the character of being an accomplished gentleman, and a man of honour.—Well, that's handsome enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, the fellow had some design in writing so—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: That he had, I'll answer for him, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: But go on, Sir—you'll see presently.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: As for the old weather-beaten she-dragon who guards you,—Who can he mean by that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Me, Sir—me—he means me there— what do you think now?—but go on a little further.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Impudent scoundrel!—it shall go hard but I will elude her vigilance, as I am told that the same ridiculous vanity, which makes her dress up her coarse features, and deck her dull chat with hard words which she don't understand—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: There, Sir! an attack upon my language! what do you think of that?—an aspersion upon my parts of speech! was ever such a brute! save if I reprehend any thing in this world, it is the use of my oracular tongue, and a nice derangement of epitaphs!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: He deserves to be hang'd and quartered! let me see—same ridiculous vanity—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You need not read it again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Ma'am does also lay her open to the grossest deceptions from flattery and pretended admiration—an impudent coxcomb! so that I have a scheme to see you shortly with the old Harridan's consent, and even to make her a go between in our interviews.—Was ever such assurance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any thing like it? —he'll elude my vigilance, will he?—yes, yes! ha! ha! he's very likely to enter these floors!— we'll try who can plot best!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! had a conceited puppy, ha! ha! ha!—Well, but Mrs. Malaprop, as the girl seems so infatuated by this fellow, suppose you were to wink at her corresponding with him for
a little time—let her even plot an elopement with him—then do you connive at her escape—while I, just in the nick, will have the fellow laid by the heels, and fairly contrive to carry her off in his stead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am delighted with the scheme, never was any thing better perpetrated!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: But, pray, could not I see the lady for a few minutes now?—I should like to try her temper a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, I don't know—I doubt she is not prepared for a first visit of this kind.— There is a decorum in these matters.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O Lord! she won't mind me—only tell her Beverley—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Gently, good tongue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: What did you say of Beverley?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, I was going to propose that you should tell her, by way of jest, that it was Beverley who was below—she'd come down fast enough then—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: 'Twould be a trick she well-deserves —besides you know the fellow tells her he'll get my consent to see her—ha! ha!—Let him if he can, I say again.—Lydia, come down here!
—He'll make me a go-between in their interviews! —ha! ha! ha! Come down, I say, Lydia!—I don't wonder at your laughing, ha! ha! ha! his impudence is truly ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: 'Tis very ridiculous, upon my soul, Ma'am, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: The little hussy won't hear.—Well, I'll go and tell her at once who it is—she shall know that Capt. Absolute is come to wait on her. —And I'll make her behave as becomes a young woman.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: As you please, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: For the present, Captain, your servant—Ah! you've not done laughing yet, I see— elude my vigilance! yes, yes, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! one would think now that I might throw off all disguise at once, and seize my prize with security—but such is Lydia's caprice, that to undeceive were probably to lose her. —I'll see whether she knows me.

div2.stage: [Walks aside, and seems engaged in looking at the pictures.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What a scene am I now to go thro'! surely nothing can be more dreadful than to be obliged to listen to the loathsome addresses of a stranger to one's heart.—I have heard of girls persecuted as I am, who have appealed in behalf of their favoured lover to the generosity of his rival: suppose I were to try it—there stands the hated rival—an officer too!—but O how unlike my Beverley!— I wonder he don't begin—truly he seems a very negligent wooer!—quite at his ease, upon my word! I'll speak first—Mr. Absolute.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Beverley!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Hush!—hush, my life!—softly! be not surprised!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I am so astonished! and so terrified! and so overjoy'd!—for Heav'n's sake! how came you here?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Briefly—I have deceived your Aunt—I was informed that my new rival was to visit here this evening, and contriving to have him kept away, have passed myself on her for Capt. Absolute.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O, charming!—And she really takes you for young Absolute?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, she's convinced of it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I can't forbear laughing to think how her sagacity is over-reached!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: But we trifle with our precious moments— such another opportunity may not occur—then let me now conjure my kind, my condescending angel, to fix the time when I may rescue her from undeserved persecution, and with a licensed warmth plead for my reward.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Will you then, Beverley, consent to forfeit that portion of my paltry wealth?—that burthen on the wings of love?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O come to me—rich only thus—in loveliness—Bring no portion to me but thy love—'twill be generous in you, Lydia—for well you know, it is the only dower your poor Beverley can repay.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How persuasive are his words!—how charming will poverty be with him!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Ah! my soul, what a life will we then live? Love shall be our idol and support! we will worship him with a monastic strictness; abjuring all worldly toys, to center every thought and action there.—Proud of calamity, we will enjoy the wreck of wealth; while the surrounding gloom of adversity shall make the flame of our pure love show doubly bright.—By Heav'ns! I would fling all goods of fortune from me with a prodigal hand to enjoy the scene where I might clasp my Lydia to my bosom, and say, the world affords no smile to me—but here—
If she holds out now the devil is in it!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now could I fly with him to the Antipodes! but my persecution is not yet come to a crisis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I'm impatient to know how the little huzzy deports herself.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: So pensive, Lydia!—is then your warmth abated?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Warmth abated!—so!—she has been in a passion, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No—nor ever can while I have life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: An ill-temper'd little devil!—She'll be in a passion all her life—will she?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Think not the idle threats of my ridiculous aunt can ever have any weight with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Very dutiful, upon my word!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Let her choice be Capt. Absolute, but Beverley is mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am astonished at her assurance!— to his face—this to his face!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Thus then let me enforce my suit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye—poor young man!—down on his knees entreating for pity!—I can contain no longer.—Why, huzzy! huzzy!—I have overheard you.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O confound her vigilance!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Capt. Absolute—I know not how to apologize for her shocking rudeness.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: So—all's safe, I find.
I have hopes, Madam, that time will bring the young lady—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, there's nothing to be hoped for from her! she's as headstrong as an allegory on the banks of Nile.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, what do you charge me with now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, thou unblushing rebel—didn't you tell this gentleman to his face that you loved another better?—didn't you say you never would be his?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No, Madam—I did not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Good Heav'ns! what assurance!— Lydia, Lydia, you ought to know that lying don't
become a young woman!—Didn't you boast that Beverley—that stroller Beverley, possessed your heart?—Tell me that, I say.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Ma'am, and none but Beverley—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Hold;—hold Assurance!—you shall not be so rude.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nay, pray Mrs. Malaprop, don't stop the young lady's speech:—she's very welcome to talk thus—it does not hurt me in the least, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You are too good, Captain—too amiably patient—but come with me, Miss—let us see you again soon, Captain—remember what we have fixed.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I shall, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, take a graceful leave of the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: May every blessing wait on my Beverley, my lov'd Bev—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Huzzy! I'll choak the word in your throat!—come along—come along.

div2.stage: [Beverley kissing his hand to Lydia—Mrs. Malaprop stopping her from speaking.

div2.head: SCENE V. Acres's lodgings.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Indeed, David—do you think I become it so?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: You are quite another creature, believe me Master, by the Mass! an' we've any luck we shall see the Devon monkeyrony in all the printshops in Bath!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Dress does make a difference, David.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: 'Tis all in all, I think—difference! why, an' you were to go now to Clod-Hall, I am certain the old lady wouldn't know you: Master Butler wouldn't believe his own eyes, and Mrs. Pickle would cry, "Lard presarve me!" our dairy-maid would come giggling to the door, and I warrant Dolly Tester, your Honour's favourite, would blush like my waistcoat.—Oons! I'll hold a gallon, there an't a dog in the house but would bark, and I question whether Phillis would wag a hair of her tail!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, David, there's nothing like polishing.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: So I says of your Honour's boots; but the boy never heeds me!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But, David, has Mr. De-la-Grace been here? I must rub up my balancing, and chasing, and boring.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I'll call again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Do—and see if there are any letters for me at the post-office.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I will.—By the Mass, I can't help looking at your head!—if I hadn't been by at the cooking, I wish I may die if I should have known the dish again myself!

div2.stage: [Acres comes forward, practising a dancing step.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p:
Sink, slide—coupee—Confound the first inventors of cotillons! say I—they are as bad as algebra to us country gentlemen—I can walk a Minuet easy enough when I'm forced!—and I have been accounted a good stick in a Country-dance. —Odd's jigs and tabors!—I never valued your crossover two couple—figure in—right and left—and I'd foot it with e'er a captain in the county!—but these outlandish heathen Allemandes and Cotillons are quite beyond me!—I shall never prosper at 'em, that's sure—mine are true-born English legs— they don't understand their curst French lingo!
—their Pas this, and Pas that, and Pas t'other!— d—n me, my feet don't like to be called Paws! no, 'tis certain I have most Antigallican Toes!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here is Sir Lucius O'Trigger to wait on you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Shew him in.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Acres, I am delighted to embrace you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: My dear Sir Lucius, I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, my friend, what has brought you so suddenly to Bath?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Faith! I have followed Cupid's Jack-a-Lantern, and find myself in a quagmire at last.— In short, I have been very ill-used, Sir Lucius.— I don't choose to mention names, but look on me as on a very ill-used gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, what is the case?—I ask no names.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mark me, Sir Lucius, I falls as deep as need be in love with a young lady—her friends take my part—I follow her to Bath—send word of my arrival; and receive answer, that the lady is to be otherwise disposed of.—This, Sir Lucius, I call being ill-used.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Very ill, upon my conscience—Pray, can you divine the cause of it?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, there's the matter: she has another lover, one Beverley, who, I am told, is now in Bath. —Odds slanders and lies! he must be at the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: A rival in the case, is there?—and you think he has supplanted you unfairly.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Unfairly!—to be sure he has.—He never could have done it fairly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then sure you know what is to be done!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Not I, upon my soul!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: We wear no swords here, but you understand me.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What! fight him!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye, to be sure: what can I mean else?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But he has given me no provocation.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now, I think he has given you the greatest provocation in the world.—Can a man commit a more heinous offence against another than to fall in love with the same woman? O, by my soul, it is the most unpardonable breach of friendship!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Breach of friendship! Aye, aye; but I have no acquaintance with this man. I never saw him in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: That's no argument at all—he has the less right then to take such a liberty.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: 'Gad that's true—I grow full of anger, Sir Lucius!—I fire apace! Odds hilts and blades! I find a man may have a deal of valour in him, and not know it! But couldn't I contrive to have a little right of my side?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What the d—l signifies right, when your honour is concerned? Do you think Achilles, or my little Alexander the Great ever inquired where the right lay? No, by my soul, they drew their broad-swords, and left the lazy sons of peace to settle the justice of it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Your words are a grenadier's march to my heart! I believe courage must be catching!— I certainly do feel a kind of valour rising as it were —a kind of courage, as I may say—Odds flints, pans, and triggers! I'll challenge him directly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Ah, my little friend! if we had Blunderbuss-Hall here—I could shew you a range of ancestry,
in the O'Trigger line, that would furnish the new room; every one of whom had killed his man!—For though the mansion-house and dirty acres have slipt through my fingers, I thank God our honour, and the family-pictures, are as fresh as ever.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O Sir Lucius! I have had ancestors too! every man of 'em colonel or captain in the militia?—Odds balls and barrels! say no more—I'm brac'd for it—my nerves are become catgut! my sinews wire! and my heart Pinchbeck! The thunder of your words has soured the milk of human kindness in my breast!—Z—ds! as the man in the play says, "I could do such deeds!"

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Come, come, there must be no passion at all in the case—these things should always be done civilly.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: I must be in a passion, Sir Lucius—I must be in a rage—Dear Sir Lucius let me be in a rage, if you love me.—Come, here's pen and paper.
I would the ink were red!—Indite, I say, indite!—How shall I begin? Odds bullets and blades! I'll write a good bold hand, however.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray compose yourself.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Come—now shall I begin with an oath? Do, Sir Lucius, let me begin with a damme.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! pho! do the thing decently and like a Christian. Begin now,—"Sir—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: That's too civil by half.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "To prevent the confusion that might arise."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "From our both addressing the same lady."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—there's the reason—"same lady"— Well—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: "I shall expect the honour of your company"—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! I'm not asking him to dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray be easy.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well then, "honour of your company"

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: To settle our pretensions."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Let me see, aye, King's Mead-fields will do.—"In King's Mead fields."

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: So that's done.—Well, I'll fold it up presently; my own crest—a hand and dagger shall be the seal.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: You see now this little explanation will put a stop at once to all confusion or misunderstanding that might arise between you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, we fight to prevent any misunderstanding.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now, I'll leave you to fix your own time.—take my advice, and you'll decide it this evening if you can; then let the worst come of it, 'twill be off your mind to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: So I shall see nothing more of you, unless it be by letter, till the evening.—I would do myself the honour to carry your message; but, to tell you a secret, I believe I shall have just such another affair on my own hands. There is a gay captain here, who put a jest on me lately, at the expence of my country, and I only want to fall in with the gentleman, to call him out.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: By my valour, I should like to see you fight first! Odds life! I should like to see you kill him, if it was only to get a little lesson.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I shall be very proud of instructing you. —Well for the present—but remember now, when you meet your antagonist, do every thing in a mild and agreeable manner.—Let your courage be as keen, but at the same time as polished as your sword.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: THEN, by the Mass, Sir! I would do no such thing—ne'er a Sir Lucius O'Trigger in the kingdom should make me fight, when I wa'n't so minded. Oons! what will the old lady say, when she hears o't!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Ah! David, if you had heard Sir Lucius!—Odds sparks and flames! he would have rous'd your valour.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Not he, indeed. I hates such bloodthirsty cormorants. Look'ee, Master, if you'd wanted a bout at boxing, quarter-staff, or shortstaff, I should never be the man to bid you cry off: But for your curst sharps and snaps, I never knew any good come of 'em.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But my honour, David, my honour! I must be very careful of my honour.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Aye, by the Mass! and I would be very careful of it; and I think in return my honour couldn't do less than to be very careful of me.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds blades! David, no gentleman will ever risk the loss of his honour!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
I say then, it would be but civil in honour never to risk the loss of the gentleman.— Lookee, Master, this honour seems to me to be a marvellous
false friend; aye, truly, a very courtier-like servant.—Put the case, I was a gentleman (which, thank God, no one can say of me); well—my honour makes me quarrel with another gentleman of my acquaintance.—So—we fight. (Pleasant enough that) Boh!—I kill him—(the more's my luck.) Now, pray who gets the profit of it?—Why, my honour.—But put the case that he kills me!— by the Mass! I go to the worms, and my honour whips over to my enemy!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, David—in that case!—Odds crowns and laurels! your honour follows you to the grave.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Now, that's just the place where I could make a shift to do without it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds, David! you're a coward!— It doesn't become my valour to listen to you.— What, shall I disgrace my ancestors?—Think of that, David—think what it would be to disgrace my ancestors!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Under favour, the surest way of not disgracing them, is to keep as long as you can out of their company. Look'ee now, Master, to go to them in such haste—with an ounce of lead in your brains—I should think might as well be let alone. Our ancestors are very good kind of folks; but they are the last people I should choose to have a visiting acquaintance with.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But David, now, you don't think there is such very, very, very great danger, hey?— Odds life! people often fight without any mischief done!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
By the Mass, I think 'tis ten to one against you!—Oons! here to meet some lionheaded fellow, I warrant, with his d—n'd doublebarrell'd swords, and cut and thrust pistols! Lord bless us! it makes me tremble to think o't!— Those be such desperate bloody-minded weapons!
Well, I never could abide 'em!—from a child I never could fancy 'em!—I suppose there a'n't so merciless a beast in the world as your loaded pistol!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! I won't be afraid—Odds fire and fury! you shan't make me afraid.—Here is the challenge, and I have sent for my dear friend Jack Absolute to carry it for me.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Aye, I'the name of mischief, let him be the messenger.—For my part, I wouldn't lend a hand to it for the best horse in your stable. By the Mass! it don't look like another letter!—It is, as I may say, a designing and malicious-looking letter!—and I warrant smells of gunpowder like a soldier's pouch!—Oons! I wouldn't swear it mayn't go off!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Out, you poltroon!—you ha'n't the valour of a grass-hopper.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Well, I say no more—'twill be sad news, to be sure, at Clod-Hall!—but I ha' done.—How Phyllis will howl when she hears of it!—Aye, poor bitch, she little thinks what shooting her Master's going after!—And I warrant old Crop, who has carried your honour, field and road, these ten years, will curse the hour he was born.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: It won't do, David—I am determined to fight—so get along, you Coward, while I'm in the mind.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Captain Absolute, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O! shew him up.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Well, Heaven send we be all alive this time to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What's that!—Don't provoke me, David!

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Good bye, Master.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Getalong, you cowardly, dastardly, croaking raven.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: What's the matter, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A vile, sheep-hearted blockhead!—If I hadn't the valour of St. George and the dragon to boot—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: But what did you want with me, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O!—There—(Gives him the challenge.)

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: "To Ensign Beverley." So—what's going on now!
Well, what's this?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A challenge!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Indeed!—Why, you won't fight him; will you, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: 'Egad but I will, Jack.—Sir Lucius has wrought me to it. He has left me full of rage—and I'll fight this evening, that so much good passion mayn't be wasted.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: But what have I to do with this?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, as I think you know something of this fellow, I want you to find him out for me, and give him this mortal defiance.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Well, give it to me, and trust me he gets it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear friend, my dear Jack; but it is giving you a great deal of trouble.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Not in the least—I beg you won't mention it.—No trouble in the world, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: You are very kind.—What it is to have a friend!—You couldn't be my second— could you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Why no, Bob—not in this affair—it would not be quite so proper.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Well then I must fix on my friend Sir Lucius. I shall have your good wishes, however, Jack.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Whenever he meets you, believe me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Anthony Absolute is below, inquiring for the Captain.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I'll come instantly.—Well, my little hero, success attend you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Stay—stay, Jack.—If Beverley should ask you what kind of a man your friend Acres is, do, tell him I am a devil of a fellow—will you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: To be sure I shall.—I'll say you are a determined dog—hey, Bob!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye, do, do—and if that frightens him, 'egad perhaps he mayn't come. So tell him I generally kill a man a week; will you, Jack!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I will, I will; I'll say you are call'd in the country "Fighting Bob!"

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Right, right—'tis all to prevent mischief; for I don't want to take his life if I clear my honour.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: No!—that's very kind of you.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Why, you don't wish me to kill him—do you, Jack?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: No, upon my soul, I do not.—But a devil of a fellow, hey?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: True, true—but stay—stay, Jack—you may add that you never saw me in such a rage before —a most devouring rage!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Remember, Jack—a determined dog!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Aye, aye, "Fighting Bob!"

div2.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p:
Why, thou perverse one!—tell me what you can object to him?—Isn't he a handsome
man?—tell me that.—A genteel man? a pretty figure of a man?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: She little thinks whom she is praising! (aside)—So is Beverley, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: No caparisons, Miss, if you please! —Caparisons don't become a young woman.—No! Captain Absolute is indeed a fine gentleman!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Aye, the Captain Absolute you have seen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Then he's so well bred;—so full of alacrity, and adulation!—and has so much to say for himself:—in such good language too!—His physiognomy so grammatical!—Then his presence is so noble!—I protest, when I saw him, I thought of what Hamlet says in the Play:—Hesperian curls!—the front of Job himself!—an eye, like March, to threaten at command!—a Station, like Harry Mercury, new— Something about kissing—on a hill—however, the similitudé struck me directly.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How enraged she'll be presently when she discovers her mistake!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Anthony, and Captain Absolute are below Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Shew them up here. [Exit Serv. Now, Lydia, I insist on your behaving as becomes a young woman.—Shew your good breeding at least, though you have forgot your duty.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Madam, I have told you my resolution;—I shall not only give him no encouragement, but I won't even speak to, or look at him.

div2.stage: [Flings herself into a chair, with her face from the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Here we are, Mrs. Malaprop; come to mitigate the frowns of unrelenting beauty—and
difficulty enough I had to bring this fellow.—I don't know what's the matter; but if I hadn't held him by force, he'd have given me the slip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You have infinite trouble, Sir Anthony, in the affair.—I am ashamed for the cause! Lydia, Lydia, rise I beseech you!—pay your respects!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, that Miss Languish has reflected on the worth of this gentleman, and the regard due to her Aunt's choice, and my alliance. —Now, Jack, speak to her!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: What the d—I shall I do!—(Aside)—You see, Sir, she won't even look at me, whilst you are here.—I knew she wouldn't!—I told you so—Let me intreat you, Sir, to leave us together!

div2.stage: [Absolute seems to expostulate with his Father.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (aside.) I wonder I ha'n't heard my Aunt exclaim yet! sure she can't have look'd at him! —perhaps their regimentals are alike, and she is something blind.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: I say, Sir, I won't stir a foot yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: I am sorry to say, Sir Anthony, that my affluence over my Niece is very small.—Turn round Lydia, I blush for you!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: May I not flatter myself that Miss Languish will assign what cause of dislike she can have to my son!—Why don't you begin, Jack?— Speak, you puppy—speak!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: It is impossible, Sir Anthony, she can have any.—She will not say she has.— Answer, hussy! why don't you answer?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Then, Madam, I trust that a childish and hasty predilection will be no bar to Jack's happiness.—Z—ds! sirrah! why don't you speak?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
(aside) I think my lover seems as little inclined
to conversation as myself.—How strangely blind my Aunt is!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Hem! hem!—Madam—hem! (Absolute attempts to speak, then returns to Sir Anthony)— Faith! Sir, I am so confounded!—and so—so— confused!—I told you I should be so, Sir,—I knew it—The-the-tremor of my passion, entirely takes away my presence of mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: But it don't take away your voice, fool, does it?—Go up, and speak to her directly!
sp.stage: [Abs. makes signs to Mrs. Mal. to leave them together.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Anthony, shall we leave them together? —Ah! you stubborn, little vixen!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Not yet, Ma'am, not yet!—what the d—l are you at? unlock your jaws, sirrah, or—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Now Heav'n send she may be too sullen to look round!—I must disguise my voice—(Aside)—
—Will not Miss Languish lend an ear to the mild accents of true love?—Will not—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What the d—l ails the fellow?— Why don't you speak out?—not stand croaking like a frog in a quinsey!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: The—the—excess of my awe, and my—my— my modesty, quite choak me!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ah! your modesty again!—I'll tell you what, Jack; if you don't speak out directly, and glibly too, I shall be in such a rage!—Mrs. Malaprop, I wish the lady would favour us with something more than a side-front!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: So!—all will out I see!
Be not surprised, my Lydia, suppress all surprise at present.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (aside) Heav'ns! 'tis Beverley's voice!— Sure he can't have impos'd on Sir Anthony too!—
sp.stage: [Looks round by degrees, then starts up.
sp.p: Is this possible!—my Beverley!—how can this be? —my Beverley?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis all over.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Beverley!—the devil—Beverley!— What can the girl mean?—This is my son, Jack Absolute!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: For shame, hussy! for shame!— your head runs so on that fellow, that you have him always in your eyes!—beg Captain Absolute's pardon directly.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I see no Captain Absolute, but my lov'd Beverley!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! the girl's mad!—her brain's turn'd by reading!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O' my conscience, I believe so!— what do you mean by Beverley, hussy?—You saw Captain Absolute before to-day; there he is— your husband that shall be.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: With all my soul, Ma'am—when I refuse my Beverley—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O! she's as mad as Bedlam!—or has this fellow been playing us a rogue's trick!—Come here, sirrah! who the d—l are you?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I am not quite clear myself; but I'll endeavour to recollect.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Are you my son, or not?—answer for your mother, you dog, if you won't for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, who are you? O mercy! I begin to suspect!—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Ye Powers of Impudence befriend me! (aside) Sir Anthony, most assuredly I am your wife's son; and that I sincerely believe myself to be your's also, I hope my duty has always shewn. —Mrs. Malaprop, I am your most respectful admirer —and shall be proud to add affectionate nephew.
—I need not tell my Lydia, that she sees her faithful Beverley, who, knowing the singular generosity of her temper, assum'd that name, and a station, which has proved a test of the most disinterested love, which he now hopes to enjoy in a a more elevated character.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So!—there will be no elopement after all!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Upon my soul, Jack, thou art a very impudent fellow! to do you justice, I think I never saw a piece of more consummate assurance!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, you flatter me, Sir—you compliment— 'tis my modesty you know, Sir—my modesty that has stood in my way.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well, I am glad you are not the dull, insensible varlet you pretended to be, however!— I'm glad you have made a fool of your father, you dog—I am.—So this was your penitence, your duty, and obedience!—I thought it was d—n'd sudden! —You never heard their names before, not you! —What, Languishes of Worcestershire, hey?—if you could please me in the affair, 'twas all you desired!— Ah! you dissembling villain!—What! (pointing to Lydia) she squints, don't she?—a little red-hair'd girl!—hey?—Why, you hypocritical young rascal —I wonder you a'n't asham'd to hold up your head!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: 'Tis with difficulty, Sir—I am confus'd— very much confus'd, as you must perceive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Lud! Sir Anthony!—a new light breaks in upon me!—hey! how! what! Captain, did you write the letters then?—What!—I am to thank you for the elegant compilation of 'an old weather-beaten she-dragon'—hey?—O mercy!—was it you that reflected on my parts of speech?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Dear Sir! my modesty will be overpower'd at last, if you don't assist me.—I shall certainly not be able to stand it!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, come, Mrs. Malaprop, we must forget and forgive;—odds'life! matters have taken so clever a turn all of a sudden, that I could find in my heart, to be so good-humour'd! and so gallant!—hey! Mrs. Malaprop!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Well, Sir Anthony, since you desire it, we will not anticipate the past;—so mind young people—our retrospection will now be all to the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, we must leave them together; Mrs. Malaprop, they long to fly into each other's arms, I warrant!—Jack—is'n't the cheek as I said, hey?—and the eye, you dog!—and the lip—hey? Come, Mrs. Malaprop, we'll not disturb their tenderness—their's is the time of life for happiness! —"Youth's the season made for joy"—(sings) —hey!—Odds'life! I'm in such spirits,—I don't know what I couldn't do!—Permit me, Ma'am— (gives his hand to Mrs. Mal.) (sings) Tol-de-rol— 'gad I should like a little fooling myself—Tol-derol! de-rol!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: So much thought bodes me no good (aside) —So grave, Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: So!—egad! I thought as much!—that d—n'd monosyllable has froze me! (aside)—What, Lydia, now that we are as happy in our friends consent, as in our mutual vows—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Friends consent, indeed! (peevishly)

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Come, come, we must lay aside some of our romance—a little wealth and comfort may be endur'd after all. And for your fortune, the lawyers shall make such settlements as—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Lawyers! I hate lawyers!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nay then, we will not wait for their lingering forms, but instantly procure the licence, and—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: The licence!—I hate licence!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O my Love! be not so unkind!—thus let me intreat—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Pshaw!—what signifies kneeling, when you know I must have you?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: (rising) Nay, Madam, there shall be no constraint upon your inclinations, I promise you. —If I have lost your heart,—I resign the rest.— 'Gad, I must try what a little spirit will do.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (rising) Then, Sir, let me tell you, the interest you had there was acquired by a mean, unmanly imposition, and deserves the punishment of fraud.—What, you have been treating me like a child!—humouring my romance! and laughing, I suppose, at your success!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: You wrong me, Lydia, you wrong me— only hear—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So, while I fondly imagined we were deceiving my relations, and flatter'd myself that I should outwit and incense them all—behold! my hopes are to be crush'd at once, by my Aunt's consent and approbation!—and I am myself, the only dupe at last!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nay, but hear me—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: No, Sir, you could not think that such paltry artifices could please me, when the mask was thrown off!—But I suppose since your tricks have made you secure of my fortune, you are little solicitous about my affections.—But here, Sir, here is the picture—Beverley's picture! (taking a miniature from her bosom) which I have worn, night and day, in spite of threats and entreaties!— There, Sir, (flings it to him) and be assured I throw the original from my heart as easily!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, Ma'am, we will not differ as to that.—Here, (taking out a picture) here is Miss Lydia Languish.—What a difference!—aye, there is the heav'nly assenting smile, that first gave soul
and spirit to my hopes!—those are the lips which seal'd a vow, as yet scarce dry in Cupid's calendar! —and there the half resentful blush, that would have check'd the ardour of my thanks—Well, all that's past!—all over indeed!—There, Madam— in beauty, that copy is not equal to you, but in my mind it's merit over the original, in being still the same, is such—that—I cannot find in my heart to part with it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: (Softening) 'Tis your own doing, Sir—I, I, I suppose you are perfectly satisfied.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, most certainly—sure now this is much better than being in love!—ha! ha! ha!—there's some spirit in this!—What signifies breaking some scores of solemn promises, half an hundred vows, under one's hand, with the marks of a dozen or two angels to witness—all that's of no consequence you know.—To be sure people will say, that Miss didn't know her own mind—but never mind that:— or perhaps they may be ill-natured enough to hint, that the gentleman grew tired of the lady and forsook her—but don't let that fret you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: There's no bearing his insolence.

div2.stage: Enter Mrs. Malaprop and Sir Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: (Entering) Come, we must interrupt your billing and cooing a while.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: This is worse than your treachery and deceit, you base ingrate!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter now!— Z—ds! Mrs. Malaprop, this is the oddest billing and cooing I ever heard!—but what the deuce is the meaning of it?—I'm quite astonish'd!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Ask the lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O mercy!—I'm quite analys'd for my part!—why, Lydia, what is the reason of this?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ask the gentleman, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! I shall be in a phrenzy!— why Jack, you scoundrel, you are not come out to be any one else, are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, there's no more trick, is there?—you are not like Cerberus, three Gentlemen at once, are you?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: You'll not let me speak—I say the lady can account for this much better than I can.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ma'am, you once commanded me never to think of Beverley again—there is the man—I now obey you:—for, from this moment, I renounce him for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O mercy! and miracles! what a turn here is—why sure, Captain, you haven't behaved disrespectfully to my Niece.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—ha! ha! ha!—now I see it—Ha! ha! ha!—now I see it—you have been too lively, Jack.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, upon my word—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, no lying, Jack—I'm sure 'twas so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Lud! Sir Anthony!—O fie, Captain!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Upon my soul, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, no excuses, Jack;—why, your father, you rogue, was so before you:—the blood of the Absolutes was always impatient.—Ha! ha! ha! poor little Lydia!—why, you've frighten'd her, you Dog, you have.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: By all that's good, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p:
Z—ds! say no more, I tell you.— Mrs. Malaprop shall make your peace.—You must make his peace, Mrs. Malaprop;—you must tell her 'tis Jack's way—tell her 'tis all our ways— it runs in the blood of our family!—Come, get on,
Jack,—ha! ha! ha! Mrs. Malaprop—a young villain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O! Sir Anthony!—O fie, Captain!

div2.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I wonder where this Capt. Absolute hides himself.—Upon my conscience!—these officers are always in one's way in love-affairs:—I remember I might have married Lady Dorothy Carmine, if it had not been for a little rogue of a Major, who ran away with her before she could get a sight of me!—And I wonder too what it is the ladies can see in them to be so fond of them—unless it be a touch of the old serpent in 'em, that makes the little creatures be caught, like vipers with a bit of red cloth.—Hah!—isn't this the Captain coming? —faith it is!—There is a probability of succeeding about that fellow, that is mighty provoking! —Who the devil is he talking to?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: To what fine purpose I have been plotting! a noble reward for all my schemes, upon my soul!—a little gypsey!—I did not think her romance could have made her so d—n'd absurd either—S'death, I never was in a worse humour in my life!—I could cut my own throat, or any other person's, with the greatest pleasure in the world!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
O, faith! I'm in the luck of it—I never could have found him in a sweeter temper for
my purpose—to be sure I'm just come in the nick! now to enter into conversation with him, and so quarrel genteelly. [Sir Lucius goes up to Absolute. —With regard to that matter, Captain, I must beg leave to differ in opinion with you.

sp.speaker: Abs
sp.p: Upon my word then, you must be a very subtle disputant:—because, Sir, I happen'd just then to be giving no opinion at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: That's no reason.—For give me leave to tell you, a man may think an untruth as well as speak one.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Very true, Sir, but if the man never utters his thoughts, I should think they might stand a chance of escaping controversy.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you differ in opinion with me, which amounts to the same thing.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Sir Lucius,—if I had not before known you to be a gentleman, upon my soul, I should not have discovered it at this interview:— for what you can drive at, unless you mean to quarrel with me, I cannot conceive!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir, for the quickness of your apprehension, [Bowing. —you have nam'd the very thing I would be at.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—I shall certainly not baulk your inclinations:—but I should be glad you would please to explain your motives.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be easy—the quarrel is a very pretty quarrel as it stands—we should only spoil it, by trying to explain it.—However, your memory is very short—or you could not have forgot an affront you pass'd on me within this week.—So no more, but name your time and place.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you are so bent on it, the sooner the better;—let it be this evening—here, by the Spring-Gardens.—We shall scarcely be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Faith! that same interruption in affairs of this nature, shews very great ill-breeding.— I don't know what's the reason, but in England, if a thing of this kind gets wind, people make such a pother, that a gentleman can never fight in peace and quietness.—However, if it's the same to you, Captain, I should take it as a particular kindness, if you'd let us meet in King's-Mead-Fields, as a little business will call me there about six o'clock, and I may dispatch both matters at once.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: 'Tis the same to me exactly.—A little after six, then we will discuss this matter more seriously.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: If you please, Sir, there will be very pretty small-sword light, tho' it won't do for a long shot.—So that matter's settled! and my mind's at ease.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Well met.—I was going to look for you.— O, Faulkand! all the Daemons of spite and disappointment have conspired against me! I'm so vex'd, that if I had not the prospect of a resource in being knock'd o'the head by and bye, I should scarce have spirits to tell you the cause.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: What can you mean?—Has Lydia chang'd her mind?—I should have thought her duty and inclination would now have pointed to the same object.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Aye, just as the eyes do of a person who squints:—when her love-eye was fix'd on me— t'other—her eye of duty, was finely obliqued:—but when duty bid her point that the same way—off t'other turn'd on a swivel, and secured its retreat with a frown!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: But what's the resource you—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
O, to wind up the whole, a good natured Irishman here has (mimicking Sir Lucius) beg'd
leave to have the pleasure of cutting my throat— and I mean to indulge him—that's all.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Prithee, be serious.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: 'Tis fact, upon my soul.—Sir Lucius O'Trigger—you know him by sight—for some affront, which I am sure I never intended, has obliged me to meet him this evening at six o'clock: —'tis on that account I wish'd to see you—you must go with me.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, there must be some mistake, sure. —Sir Lucius shall explain himself—and I dare say matters may be accommodated:—but this evening, did you say?—I wish it had been any other time.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Why?—there will be light enough:— there will (as Sir Lucius says) "be very pretty small-sword light, tho' it won't do for a long shot."—Confound his long shots!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: But I am myself a good deal ruffled, by a difference I have had with Julia—my vile tormenting temper has made me treat her so cruelly, that I shall not be myself till we are reconciled.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: By Heav'ns, Faulkland, you don't deserve her.

div2.stage: Enter Servant, gives Faulkland a letter.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Jack! this is from Julia—I dread to open it—I fear it may be to take a last leave— perhaps to bid me return her letters—and restore —O! how I suffer for my folly!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Here—let me see.
Aye, a final sentence indeed!—'tis all over with you, faith!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, Jack—don't keep me in suspence.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Hear then.—As I am convinced that my dear Faulkland's own reflections have already upbraided
braided him for his last unkindness to me, I will not add a word on the subject.—I wish to speak with you as soon as possible.
—Your's ever and truly, Julia.
—There's stubbornness and resentment for you!
Why, man, you don't seem one whit the happier at this.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O, yes, I am—but—but—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Confound your buts.—You never hear any thing that would make another man bless himself, but you immediately d—n it with a but.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now, Jack, as you are my friend, own honestly—don't you think there is something forward —something indelicate in this haste to forgive? —Women should never sue for reconciliation: —that should always come from us.—They should retain their coldness till woo'd to kindness— and their pardon, like their love, should not unsought be won.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I have not patience to listen to you:— thou'rt incorrigible!—so say no more on the subject. —I must go to settle a few matters—let me see you before six—remember—at my lodgings.— A poor industrious devil like me, who have toil'd, and drudg'd, and plotted to gain my ends, and am at last disappointed by other people's folly—may in pity be allowed to swear and grumble a little;— but a captious sceptic in love,—a slave to fretfulness and whim—who has no difficulties but of his own creating—is a subject more fit for ridicule than compassion!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p:
I feel his reproaches!—yet I would not change this too exquisite nicety, for the gross content with which he tramples on the thorns of love. —His engaging me in this duel, has started an idea in my head, which I will instantly pursue.— I'll use it as the touch-stone of Julia's sincerity and
disinterestedness—if her love prove pure and sterling ore—my name will rest on it with honour!— and once I've stamp'd it there, I lay aside my doubts for ever:—but if the dross of selfishness, the allay of pride predominate—'twill be best to leave her as a toy for some less cautious Fool to sigh for.

div2.head: SCENE I.

sp.p: How this message has alarmed me! what dreadful accident can he mean! why such charge to be alone?—O Faulkland!—how many unhappy moments!—how many tears have you cost me!

div2.stage: Enter Faulkland, muffled up in a Riding-coat.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What means this?—why this caution, Faulkland?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Alas! Julia, I am come to take a long farewell.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heav'ns! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: You see before you a wretch, whose life is forfeited.—Nay, start not!—the infirmity of my temper has drawn all this misery on me.—I left you fretful and passionate—an untoward accident drew me into a quarrel—the event is, that I must fly this kingdom instantly.—O Julia, had I been so fortunate as to have call'd you mine intirely, before this mischance had fallen on me, I should not so deeply dread my banishment!—But no more of that—your heart and promise were given to one happy in friends, character, and station! they are not bound to wait upon a solitary, guilty exile.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My soul is oppress'd with sorrow at the nature of your misfortune: had these adverse circumstances arisen from a less fatal cause, I should have felt strong comfort in the thought that I could now chase from your bosom every doubt of the warm sincerity of my love.—My heart has long known no other guardian—I now entrust my person to your honour—we will fly together.—When safe from pursuit, my Father's will may be fulfilled —and I receive a legal claim to be the partner of your sorrows, and tenderest comforter. Then on the bosom of your wedded Julia, you may lull your keen regret to slumbering; while virtuous love, with a Cherub's hand, shall smooth the brow of upbraiding thought, and pluck the thorn from compunction.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Julia! I am bankrupt in gratitude! but the time is so pressing, it calls on you for so hasty a resolution.—Would you not wish some hours to weigh the advantages you forego, and what little compensation poor Faulkland can make you beside his solitary love?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ask not a moment.—No, Faulkland, I have lov'd you for yourself: and if I now, more than ever, prize the solemn engagement which so long has pledged us to each other, it is because it leaves no room for hard aspersions on my fame, and puts the seal of duty to an act of love.—But let us not linger.—Perhaps this delay—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: 'Twill be better I should not venture out again till dark.—Yet am I griev'd to think what numberless distresses will press heavy on your gentle disposition!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Perhaps your fortune may be forfeited by this unhappy act.—I know not whether 'tis so— but sure that alone can never make us unhappy.— The little I have will be sufficient to support us; and exile never should be splendid.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Aye, but in such an abject state of life, my wounded pride perhaps may increase the natural fretfulness of my temper, till I become a rude, morose companion, beyond your patience to endure. Perhaps the recollection of a deed, my conscience cannot justify, may haunt me in such gloomy and unsocial fits, that I shall hate the tenderness that would relieve me, break from your arms, and quarrel with your fondness!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If your thoughts should assume so unhappy a bent, you will the more want some mild and affectionate spirit to watch over and console you:— One who, by bearing your infirmities with gentleness and resignation, may teach you so to bear the evils of your fortune.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: O Julia, I have proved you to the quick! and with this useless device I throw away all my doubts. How shall I plead to be forgiven this last unworthy effect of my restless, unsatisfied disposition?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Has no such disaster happened as you related?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I am ashamed to own that it was all pretended; yet in pity, Julia, do not kill me with resenting a fault which never can be repeated: But sealing, this once, my pardon, let me to-morrow, in the face of Heaven, receive my future guide and monitress, and expiate my past folly, by years of tender adoration.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Hold, Faulkland!—that you are free from a crime, which I before fear'd to name, Heaven knows how sincerely I rejoice!—These are tears of thankfulness for that! But that your cruel doubts should have urged you to an imposition that has wrung my heart, gives me now a pang, more keen than I can express!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: By Heav'ns! Julia—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yet hear me.—My Father lov'd you, Faulkland! and you preserv'd the life that tender parent gave me; in his presence I pledged my hand—joyfully pledged it—where before I had given my heart. When, soon after, I lost that parent, it seem'd to me that Providence had, in Faulkland, shewn me whither to transfer, without a pause, my grateful duty, as well as my affection: Hence I have been content to bear from you what pride and delicacy would have forbid me from another.—I will not upbraid you, by repeating how you have trifled with my sincerity.—

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: I confess it all! yet hear—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: After such a year of trial—I might have flattered myself that I should not have been insulted with a new probation of my sincerity, as cruel as unnecessary! A trick of such a nature, as to shew me plainly, that when I thought you lov'd me best, you even then regarded me as a mean dissembler; an artful, prudent hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Never! never!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I now see it is not in your nature to be content, or confident in love. With this conviction— I never will be yours. While I had hopes that my persevering attention, and unreproaching kindness might in time reform your temper, I should have been happy to have gain'd a dearer influence over you; but I will not furnish you with a licensed power to keep alive an incorrigible fault, at the expence of one who never would contend with you.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, but Julia, by my soul and honour, if after this—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
But one word more.—As my faith has once been given to you, I never will barter it with another. —I shall pray for your happiness with the truest sincerity; and the dearest blessing I can ask of
Heaven to send you, will be to charm you from that unhappy temper, which alone has prevented the performance of our solemn engagement.—All I request of you is, that you will yourself reflect upon this infirmity, and when you number up the many true delights it has deprived you of—let it not be your least regret, that it lost you the love of one— who would have follow'd you in beggary through the world!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: She's gone!—for ever!—There was an awful resolution in her manner, that rivetted me to my place.—O Fool!—Dolt!—Barbarian!— Curst as I am, with more imperfections than my fellow-wretches, kind Fortune sent a heaven-gifted cherub to my aid, and, like a ruffian, I have driven her from my side!—I must now haste to my appointment.—Well my mind is tuned for such a scene.—I shall wish only to become a principal in it, and reverse the tale my cursed folly put me upon forging here.—O Love!—Tormentor!— Fiend!—whose influence, like the Moon's, acting on men of dull souls, makes idiots of them, but meeting subtler spirits, betrays their course, and urges sensibility to madness!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Mistress, Ma'am, I know, was here just now—perhaps she is only in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Heigh ho!—Though he has used me so, this fellow runs strangely in my head. I believe one lecture from my grave Cousin will make me recall him.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
O Julia, I am come to you with such an appetite for consolation.—Lud! Child, what's the matter with you?—You have been crying!—I'll
be hanged, if that Faulkland has not been tormenting you!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You mistake the cause of my uneasiness.— Something has flurried me a little.—Nothing that you can guess at.—I would not accuse Faulkland to a Sister!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Ah! whatever vexations you may have, I can assure you mine surpass them.—You know who Beverley proves to be?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will now own to you, Lydia, that Mr. Faulkland had before inform'd me of the whole affair. Had young Absolute been the person you took him for, I should not have accepted your confidence on the subject, without a serious endeavour to counteract your caprice.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So, then, I see I have been deceived by every one!—but I don't care—I'll never have him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, Lydia—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Why, is it not provoking; when I thought we were coming to the prettiest distress imaginable, to find myself made a mere Smithfield bargain of at last—There had I projected one of the most sentimental elopements!—so becoming a disguise!—so amiable a ladder of Ropes!—Conscious Moon—four horses—Scotch parson—with such surprise to Mrs. Malaprop—and such paragraphs in the News-papers!—O, I shall die with disappointment.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I don't wonder at it!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now—sad reverse!—what have I to expect, but, after a deal of flimsy preparation with a bishop's licence, and my Aunt's blessing, to go simpering up to the Altar; or perhaps be cried three times in a country-church, and have an unmannerly fat clerk ask the consent of every butcher in the parish to join John Absolute and Lydia Languish, Spinster! O, that I should live to hear myself called Spinster!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Melancholy, indeed!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: How mortifying, to remember the dear delicious shifts I used to be put to, to gain half a minute's conversation with this fellow!—How often have I stole forth, in the coldest night in January, and found him in the garden, stuck like a dripping statue!—There would he kneel to me in the snow, and sneeze and cough so pathetically! he shivering with cold, and I with apprehension! and while the freezing blast numb'd our joints, how warmly would he press me to pity his flame, and glow with mutual ardour!—Ah, Julia! that was something like being in love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If I were in spirits, Lydia, I should chide you only by laughing heartily at you: but it suits more the situation of my mind, at present, earnestly to entreat you, not to let a man, who loves you with sincerity, suffer that unhappiness from your caprice, which I know too well caprice can inflict.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O Lud! what has brought my Aunt here!

div2.stage: Enter Mrs. Malaprop, Fag, and David.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: So! so! here's fine work!—here's fine suicide, paracide, and salivation going on in the fields! and Sir Anthony not to be found to prevent the antistrophe!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Madam, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: That gentleman can tell you—'twas he enveloped the affair to me.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Do, Sir, will you inform us.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Ma'am, I should hold myself very deficient in every requisite that forms the man of breeding, if I delay'd a moment to give all the information in my power to a lady so deeply interested in the affair as you are.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But quick! quick, Sir!

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: True, Ma'am, as you say, one should be quick in divulging matters of this nature; for should we be tedious, perhaps while we are flourishing on the subject, two or three lives may be lost!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: O patience!—Do, Ma'am, for Heaven's sake! tell us what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, murder's the matter! slaughter's the matter! killing's the matter!—but he can tell you the perpendiculars.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Then, prythee, Sir, be brief.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Why then, Ma'am—as to murder—I cannot take upon me to say—and as to slaughter, or man-slaughter, that will be as the jury finds it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But who, Sir—who are engaged in this?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Faith, Ma'am, one is a young gentleman whom I should be very sorry any thing was to happen to—a very pretty behaved gentleman!—We have lived much together, and always on terms.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But who is this? who! who! who!

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: My Master, Ma'am—my Master—I speak of my Master.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Heavens! What, Captain Absolute!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, to be sure, you are frightened now!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But who are with him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: As to the rest, Ma'am, his gentleman can inform you better than I.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do speak, friend.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Look'ee, my Lady—by the Mass! there's mischief going on.—Folks don't use to meet for amusement with fire-arms, firelocks, fire-engines, fire-screens, fire-office, and the devil knows what other crackers besides!—This, my Lady, I say, has an angry favour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But who is there beside Captain Absolute, friend?

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p:
My poor Master—under favour, for mentioning him first.—You know me, my Lady—
I am David—and my Master of course is, or was Squire Acres.—Then comes Squire Faulkland.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do, Ma'am, let us instantly endeavour to prevent mischief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O fie—it would be very inelegant in us:—we should only participate things.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ah! do, Mrs. Aunt, save a few lives— they are desperately given, believe me.—Above all, there is that blood-thirsty Philistine, Sir Lucius O'Trigger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Lucius O'Trigger!—O mercy! have they drawn poor little dear Sir Lucius into the scrape?—why, how you stand, girl! you have no more e eling than one of the Derbyshire Putrefactions!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What are we to do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, fly with the utmost felicity to be sure, to prevent mischief:—here, friend— you can shew us the place?

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: If you please, Ma'am, I will conduct you. —David, do you look for Sir Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, girls!—this gentleman will exhort us.—Come, Sir, you're our envoy—lead the way, and we'll precede.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: Not a step before the ladies for the world!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: You're sure you know the spot.

sp.speaker: Fag.
sp.p: I think I can find it, Ma'am; and one good thing is, we shall hear the report of the pistols as we draw near, so we can't well miss them; never fear, Ma'am, never fear.

div2.head: SCENE II.
div2.stage: Enter Absolute, putting his sword under his greatcoat.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: A sword seen in the streets of Bath would raise as great an alarm as a mad-dog.—How provoking this is in Faulkland!—never punctual! I shall be obliged to go without him at last.—O, the devil! here's Sir Anthony!—how shall I escape him?

div2.stage: [Muffles up his face, and takes a circle to go off.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: How one may be deceived at a little distance! only that I see he don't know me, I could have sworn that was Jack!—Hey!—'Gad's life; it is.—Why, Jack, you Dog!—what are you afraid of?—hey! sure I'm right.—Why, Jack— Jack Absolute!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Really, Sir, you have the advantage of me: —I don't remember ever to have had the honour —my name is Saunderson, at your service.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon—I took you— hey!—why, z—ds! it is—Stay—
So, so—your humble servant, Mr. Saunderson!— Why, you scoundrel, what tricks are you after now?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O! a joke, Sir, a joke!—I came here on purpose to look for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You did! well, I am glad you were so lucky:—but what are you muffled up so for? —what's this for?—hey?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Tis cool, Sir; isn't it?—rather chilly somehow—
but I shall be late—I have a particular engagement.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Stay.—why, I thought you were looking for me?—Pray, Jack, where is't you are going?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Going, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Aye—where are you going?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Where am I going?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You unmannerly puppy!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: I was going, Sir, to—to—to—to Lydia— Sir to Lydia—to make matters up if I could;— and I was looking for you, Sir, to—to—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: To go with you, I suppose—Well, come along.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O! z—ds! no, Sir, not for the world!— I wish'd to meet with you, Sir, to—to—to— You find it cool, I'm sure, Sir—you'd better not stay out.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Cool!—not at all—Well, Jack—and what will you say to Lydia?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, Sir, beg her pardon, humour her—promise and vow:—but I detain you, Sir—consider the cold air on your gout.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O, not at all!—not at all!—I'm in no hurry.—Ah! Jack, you youngsters when once you are wounded here.
Hey! what the deuce have you got here?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir—nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's this?—here's something d—d hard!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O, trinkets, Sir! trinkets—a bauble for Lydia!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Nay, let me see your taste.
sp.stage: [Pulls his coat open, the sword falls.
sp.p: Trinkets!—a bauble for Lydia!—z—ds! sirrah, you are not going to cut her throat, are you?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!—I thought it would divert
you, Sir, tho' I didn't mean to tell you till afterwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You didn't?—Yes, this is a very diverting trinket, truly.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Sir, I'll explain to you.—You know, Sir, Lydia is romantic—dev'lish romantic, and very absurd of course:—now, Sir, I intend, if she refuses to forgive me—to unsheath this sword—and swear—I'll fall upon its point, and expire at her feet!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Fall upon fiddle-sticks end!—why, I suppose it is the very thing that would please her—Get along, you Fool.—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you shall hear of my success— you shall hear.—"O, Lydia!—forgive me, or this pointed steel"—says I.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: "O, Booby! stab away, and welcome" —says she—Get along!—and d—n your trinkets!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Stop him! stop him! Murder! Thief! Fire!—Stop fire! Stop fire!—O! Sir Anthony— call! call! bid 'em stop! Murder! Fire!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Fire! Murder! where?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Oons! he's out of sight! and I'm out of breath, for my part! O, Sir Anthony, why didn't you stop him? why didn't you stop him?

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Z—ds! the fellow's mad!—Stop whom? stop Jack?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Aye, the Captain, Sir!—there's murder and slaughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Murder!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Aye, please you, Sir Anthony, there's all kinds of murder, all sorts of slaughter to be seen in the fields: there's fighting going on, Sir— bloody sword-and-gun fighting!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Who are going to fight, Dunce?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Every body that I know of, Sir Anthony: —every body is going to fight, my poor Master, Sir Lucius O'Trigger, your son, the Captain—

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: O, the Dog!—I see his tricks:—do you know the place?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: King's-Mead-Fields.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: You know the way?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Not an inch;—but I'll call the Mayor— Aldermen—Constables—Church-wardens—and Beadles—we can't be too many to part them.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come along—give me your shoulder! we'll get assistance as we go—the lying villain!— Well, I shall be in such a phrenzy—So—this was the history of his d—d trinkets! I'll bauble him!

div2.head: SCENE III.
div2.stage: Sir Lucius and Acres, with pistols.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: By my valour! then, Sir Lucius, forty yards is a good distance—Odds levels and aims!— I say it is a good distance.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Is it for muskets or small field-pieces? upon my conscience, Mr. Acres, you must leave those things to me.—Stay now—I'll shew you. [Measures paces along the stage. there now, that is a very pretty distance—a pretty gentleman's distance.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! we might as well fight in a sentrybox! —I tell you, Sir Lucius, the farther he is off, the cooler I shall take my aim.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Faith! then I suppose you would aim at him best of all if he was out of sight!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, Sir Lucius—but I should think forty or eight and thirty yards—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Pho! pho! nonsense! three or four
feet between the mouths of your pistols is as good as a mile.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds bullets, no!—by my valour! there is no merit in killing him so near:—do, my dear Sir Lucius, let me bring him down at a long shot:— a long shot, Sir Lucius, if you love me!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well—the gentleman's friend and I must settle that.—But tell me now, Mr. Acres, in case of an accident, is there any little will or commission I could execute for you?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, Sir Lucius— but I don't understand—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
