sp.p: Why, you may think there's no being shot at without a little risk—and if an unlucky bullet should carry a Quietus with it—I say it will be no time then to be bothering you about family matters.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A Quietus!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: For instance now—if that should be the case—would you chuse to be pickled and sent home?—or would it be the same to you to lie here in the Abbey?—I'm told there is very snug lying in the Abbey.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Pickled!—Snug lying in the Abbey!— Odds tremors! Sir Lucius, don't talk so!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: I suppose, Mr. Acres, you never were engaged in an affair of this kind before?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, Sir Lucius, never before.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Ah! that's a pity!—there's nothing like being used to a thing.—Pray now, how would you receive the gentleman's shot?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds files!—I've practised that—there, Sir Lucius—there [Puts himself in an attitude. —a side-front, hey?—Odd! I'll make myself small enough:—I'll stand edge-ways.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Now—you're quite out—for if you stand so when I take my aim—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds! Sir Lucius—are you sure it is not cock'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: But—but—you don't know—it may go off of its own head!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! be easy—Well, now if I hit you in the body, my bullet has a double chance—for if it misses a vital part on your right side—'twill be very hard if it don't succeed on the left!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: A vital part! O, my poor vitals!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: But, there—fix yourself so— [Placing him. let him see the broad side of your full front—there —now a ball or two may pass clear thro' your body, and never do any harm at all.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Clean thro' me!—a ball or two clean thro' me!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye—may they—and it is much the genteelest attitude into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Look'ee! Sir Lucius—I'd just as leive be shot in an aukward posture as a genteel one— so, by my valour! I will stand edge-ways

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: (Looking at his watch.) Sure they don't mean to disappoint us.—Hah?—no faith—I think I see them coming.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Hey!—what!—coming!—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Aye—Who are those yonder getting over the stile?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: There are two of them, indeed!—well— let them come—hey, Sir Lucius!—we—we—we —we—won't run.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Run!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No—I say—we won't run, by my valour!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing—my dear friend— my dear Sir Lucius—but—I-I-I don't feel quite so bold, somehow—as I did.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: O fie!—consider your honour.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—true—my honour—Do, Sir Lucius, hedge in a word or two every now and then about my honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, here they're coming.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Sir Lucius—if I wa'n't with you, I should almost think I was afraid—if my valour should leave me!—Valour will come and go.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Then, pray keep it fast, while you have it.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Sir Lucius—I doubt it is going—yes— my valour is certainly going!—it is sneaking off!— I feel it oozing out as it were at the palms of my hands!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Your honour—your honour—Here they are.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: O mercy!—now—that I were safe at Clod-Hall! or could be shot before I was aware!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your most obedient—hah! —what Captain Absolute!—So, I suppose, Sir, you are come here, just like myself—to do a kind office, first for your friend—then to proceed to business on your own account.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What, Jack!—my dear Jack!—my dear friend!

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Heark'ee, Bob, Beverley's at hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Acres—I don't blame your saluting the gentleman civilly.—So, Mr. Beverley, (to Faulkland) if you'll chuse your weapons, the Captain and I will measure the ground.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: My weapons, Sir.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds life! Sir Lucius, I'm not going to fight Mr. Faulkland; these are my particular friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: What, Sir, did not you come here to fight Mr. Acres?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, now, that's mighty provoking! But I hope, Mr. Faulkland, as there are three of us come on purpose for the game—you won't be so cantanckerous as to spoil the party by sitting out.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: O pray, Faulkland, fight to oblige Sir Lucius.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Nay, if Mr. Acres is so bent on the matter.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Faulkland—I'll bear my disappointment like a Christian—Look'ee, Sir Lucius, there's no occasion at all for me to fight; and if it is the same to you, I'd as lieve let it alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Observe me, Mr. Acres—I must not be trifled with. You have certainly challenged somebody—and you came here to fight him— Now, if that gentleman is willing to represent him —I can't see, for my soul, why it isn't just the same thing.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Z—ds, Sir Lucius—I tell you, 'tis one Beverley I've challenged—a fellow, you see, that dare not shew his face! If he were here, I'd make him give up his pretensions directly!—

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Hold, Bob—let me set you right—there is no such man as Beverley in the case.—The person who assumed that name is before you; and as his pretensions are the same in both characters, he is ready to support them in whatever way you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, this is lucky—Now you have an opportunity—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: What, quarrel with my dear friend Jack Absolute—not if he were fifty Beverleys! Z—ds! Sir Lucius, you would not have me be so unnatural.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Upon my conscience, Mr. Acres, your valour has oozed away with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p:
Not in the least! Odds Backs and Abettors! I'll be your second with all my heart—and
if you should get a Quietus, you may command me entirely. I'll get you a snug lying in the Abbey here; or pickle you, and send you over to Blunderbuss-hall, or any of the kind with the greatest pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! pho! you are little better than a coward.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mind, gentlemen, he calls me a Coward; Coward was the word, by my valour!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Look'ee, Sir Lucius, 'tisn't that I mind the word Coward—Coward may be said in joke.— But if you had call'd me a Poltroon, Odds Daggers and Balls!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: —I should have thought you a very ill-bred man.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pho! you are beneath my notice.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Lucius, you can't have a better second than my friend, Acres—He is a most determined dog—call'd in the country, Fighting Bob.—He generally kills a man a week; don't you, Bob?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Aye—at home!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Well then, Captain, 'tis we must begin —so come out, my little counsellor, [draws his sword. and ask the gentleman, whether he will resign the lady, without forcing you to proceed against him?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Come on then, Sir; (draws) since you won't let it be an amicable suit, here's my reply.

div2.stage: [Enter Sir Anthony, David, and the Women.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.p: Knock 'em all down, sweet Sir Anthony, knock down my Master in particular— and bind his hands over to their good behaviour!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Put up, Jack, put up, or I shall be in a frenzy—how came you in a duel, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that gentleman can tell you better than I; 'twas he call'd on me, and you know, Sir, I serve his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Here's a pretty fellow; I catch him going to cut a man's throat, and he tells me, he serves his Majesty!—Zounds! sirrah, then how durst you draw the King's sword against one of his subjects?

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Sir, I tell you! That gentleman call'd me out, without explaining his reasons.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gad! Sir, how came you to call my son out, without explaining your reasons?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc,
sp.p: Your son, Sir, insulted me in a manner which my honour could not brook.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Zounds! Jack, how durst you insult the gentleman in a manner which his honour could not brook?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Come, come, let's have no Honour before ladies—Captain Absolute, come here—How could you intimidate us so?—Here's Lydia has been terrified to death for you.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: For fear I should be kill'd, or escape, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, no delusions to the past—Lydia is convinc'd; speak child.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: With your leave, Ma'am, I must put in a word here—I believe I could interpret the young lady's silence—Now mark—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What is it you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Come, come, Delia, we must be serious now—this is no time for trifling.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir; and your reproof bids me offer this gentleman my hand, and solicit the return of his affections.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p:
O! my little angel, say you so?—Sir Lucius —I perceive there must be some mistake here —with regard to the affront which you affirm I have given you—I can only say, that it could not have been intentional.—And as you must be convinced,
that I should not fear to support a real injury —you shall now see that I am not ashamed to atone for an inadvertency—I ask your pardon.— But for this lady, while honour'd with her approbation, I will support my claim against any man whatever.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Well said, Jack, and I'll stand by you, my Boy.

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Mind, I give up all my claim—I make no pretensions to any thing in the world—and if I can't get a wife, without fighting for her, by my Valour! I'll live a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Captain, give me your hand—an affront handsomely acknowledged becomes an obligation —and as for the Lady—if she chuses to deny her own hand writing here—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O, he will desolve my mystery!—Sir Lucius, perhaps there's some mistake—perhaps, I can illuminate—

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Pray, old gentlewoman, don't interfere, where you have no business.—Miss Languish, are you my Delia, or not?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Lucius, I am not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Lucius O'Trigger—ungrateful as you are—I own the soft impeachment—pardon my blushes, I am Delia.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: You Delia—pho! pho! be easy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: Why, thou barbarous Vandyke— those letters are mine—When you are more sensible of my benignity—perhaps I may be brought to encourage your addresses.

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p: Mrs. Malaprop, I am extremely sensible of your condescension; and whether you or Lucy have put this trick upon me, I am equally beholden to you.—And to shew you I'm not ungrateful, Captain Absolute! since you have taken that lady from me, I'll give you my Delia into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Abs.
Sir Luc.
sp.p: Hah! little Valour—here, will you make your fortune?

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: Odds Wrinkles! No.—But give us your hand, Sir Lucius, forget and forgive; but if ever I give you a chance of pickling me again, say Bob Acres is a Dunce, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Malaprop, don't be cast down—you are in your bloom yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mal.
sp.p: O Sir Anthony!—men are all barbarians—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He seems dejected and unhappy—not sullen —there was some foundation, however, for the tale he told me—O woman! how true should be your judgment, when your resolution is so weak!

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Julia!—how can I sue for what I so little deserve? I dare not presume—yet Hope is the child of Penitence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh! Faulkland, you have not been more faulty in your unkind treatment of me, than I am now in wanting inclination to resent it. As my heart honestly bids me place my weakness to the account of love, I should be ungenerous not to admit the same plea for your's.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Now I shall be blest indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: What's going on here?—So you have been quarrelling too, I warrant.—Come, Julia, I never interfered before; but let me have a hand in the matter at last.—All the faults I have ever seen in my friend Faulkland, seemed to proceed from what he calls the delicacy and warmth of his affection for you—There, marry him directly, Julia, you'll find he'll mend surprisingly!

sp.speaker: Sir Luc.
sp.p:
Come now, I hope there is no dissatisfied person, but what is content; for as I have
been disappointed myself, it will be very hard if I have not the satisfaction of seeing other people succeed better—

sp.speaker: Acres.
sp.p: You are right, Sir Lucius.—So, Jack, I wish you joy—Mr. Faulkland the same.—Ladies, —come now, to shew you I'm neither vex'd nor angry, Odds Tabors and Pipes! I'll order the fiddles in half an hour, to the New Rooms—and I insist on you all meeting me there.

sp.speaker: Sir Anth.
sp.p: Gad! Sir, I like your spirit; and at night we single lads will drink a health to the young couples, and a husband to Mrs. Malaprop.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.p: Our partners are stolen from us, Jack— I hope to be congratulated by each other—yours for having checked in time, the errors of an illdirected Imagination, which might have betray'd an innocent heart; and mine, for having, by her gentleness and candour, reformed the unhappy temper of one, who by it made wretched whom he loved most, and tortured the heart he ought to have ador'd.

sp.speaker: Abs.
sp.p: Well, Jack, we have both tasted the Bitters, as well as the Sweets, of Love—with this difference only, that you always prepared the bitter cup for yourself, while I—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Was always obliged to me for it, hey! Mr. Modesty?—But come, no more of that— our happiness is now as unallay'd as general.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then let us study to preserve it so: and while Hope pictures to us a flattering scene of future Bliss, let us deny its pencil those colours which are too bright to be lasting.—When Hearts deserving Happiness would unite their fortune, Virtue would crown them with an unfading garland of modest, hurtless flowers; but ill-judging Passion will force the gaudier Rose into the wreath, whose thorn offends them, when its Leaves are dropt!
